phenotastic package¶

Submodules¶

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D module¶

class phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.AutoPhenotype(data=None, tags=None, contour=None, mesh=None, features=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A python class for the automated extraction of SAM features in three dimensions from a stack of confocal microscope images.

AutoPhenotype is a python class for the automated extraction of features of a shoot apical meristem (SAM) from a stack of confocal microscope images. Its main features are:

*Extraction of the SAMs surface using active contour without edges (ACWE). *Separation of the SAMs features into primordiae and the meristem. *Evaluation of the features in terms of location, size and divergence angle.

data : 3D intensity array
Image data e.g. from .tif file.

tags : unused

contour : 3D boolean array
Contour generated from data.
mesh : vtkPolyData
Mesh generated from contour. Can contain curvature values.
features : list of vtkPolyData
The extracted features from mesh.
results : panda.DataFrame
The results of the evaluation operations (e.g. sphere fit). Also contains the number of points contained in each feature and its curvature. The number of rows is the number of primordia, whereas the number of columns depends on the number of evaluation operations performed. New results are appended.
calculate_curvatures(curv_types=['mean'], operations=[])[source]¶
clean_mesh()[source]¶

Extract largest connected set in self.mesh.

Can be used to reduce residues of the contour fit inside the meristem. Works only if residues are not connected (share at least one point with) the meristems surface.

no return :
Overwrites mesh.
clear(what)[source]¶

Clear specified attributes.

Attributes to be specified can be:
*’all’ *’data’ *’tags’ *’contour’ *’mesh’ *’features’ *’results’

Specified attributes are reset into initial condition.

what : list of strings
List of attributes to be cleared. See description.
no return :
Clears attributes.
compute_normals()[source]¶
contour_fit(weighting, iterate_smooth)[source]¶

Run several full iterations of the morphological Chan-Vese method.

Implementation of Equation 32 in Marquez-Neila et al. 2014. (DOI: 10.1109/TPAMI.2013.106).

iterations : int
Number of times, the Chan-Vese Method is iterated.
weighting : float
Ratio of the weightings of the outside and inside contour.
iterate_smooth : int
Number of times, the smoothing operation is performed during one iteration.
no return :
overwrite contour.
contour_fit_threshold(threshold=0.8, smooth_iterate=3)[source]¶

Generate contour fit via a threshold.

Uses a threshold based approach to generate the initial model of self.data. Threshold default is half of the images mean intensity; can be adjusted. Subsequently, the contour is smoothed

threshold : float

Sets the threshold for a voxel to be considered in- or outside the contour.

*Inside: intensity(voxel) > mean_intensity/2*threshold *Outside: else
iterate_smooth : int
Number of times, the smoothing operation is performed.
no return :
Overwrites contour.
contour_fit_two_stage(iterations1, weighting1, iterate_smooth1, iterations2, weighting2, iterate_smooth2, zoom_factor)[source]¶

Run a two staged contour fit. First fit is on down sampled image.

The generated contour from the first fit is then up sampled and is used as initial contour for the regular fit.

iterations1,2 : int
Number of times, the Chan-Vese Method is iterated. 1 ->
weighting1,2 : float
Ratio of the weightings of the outside and inside contour.
iterate_smooth1,2 : int
Number of times, the smoothing operation is performed during one iteration.
no return :
overwrite contour.
curvature_slice(threshold=0.0, curv_types=['mean'], operations=[], lower=False)[source]¶

Slice the mesh along (negative) curvature.

Computes the curvature of the mesh and then uses a threshold filter to remove the parts with negative curvature.

no return :
Overwrites mesh.
decimate_mesh(fraction)[source]¶
feature_extraction(min_percent=1.0)[source]¶

Extract the SAM features from the sliced mesh.

Uses a vtk connectivity filter for the feature extraction. The points of the mesh are numbered. The method steps through the points (stepsize = total#ofPoints/res) and selects the connected surface in which the point lies. The selected surface is saved if:

*Its #ofPoints is larger than stepsize *It has not already been selected

(#ofPoints != #ofPoints(previous_iterations) )
min_percent : float (element of [0,100])
Minimum percentage of cells / points in a primordium / SAM to be extracted. Connected regions with less cells / points are ignored.
no return :
Overwrites features.
fill_holes(size=0.0)[source]¶
get_div_angle(sort_by='sphere_radius', sort_results=False)[source]¶

Return divergence angles for angles sorted by sort_by.

Can only be used after self.sphere_evaluation() has been used. Note: all angles must be in degree. Output is also in degree.

sort_by : str, index in self.results
specify the order in which the organs are. E.g. sort by ‘sphere_radius’ Default is ‘sphere_radius’.
sort_results : bool
Specify, if self.results should be sorted accordingly. Default is no sorting.
clockwise : float list
Difference between angles of the primordiae, clockwise orientation.
counterclockwise : float list
Difference between angles of the primordiae, counterclockwise orientation.

load(where, what=None)[source]¶

Load data to existing AutoPhenotype Object.

What is loaded can be specified.

where : string, path
Path to the folder from which the data should be loaded from.
what : either None, logfile or list of strings

*None: Logfile from specified folder is used. *logfile: No logfile is imported, instead the specified logfile is

used. E.g. generated by create_logfile() function
*list of strings: List of keywords specifying which data should be
loaded. See logfile_from_str() for more information.
no return :
Attributes are overwritten.

Fit the mersitem with a paraboloid.

Uses the first entry of self.features as meristem. See fit_paraboloid() function for more info.

no return :

New results are added to self.results *para_p1 … para_p5: Parameters of the paraboloid fit. *para_alpha,beta,gamma: Rotation of the paraboloid relative to

image.
*para_apex_x,y,z: Location of the paraboloids apex in coordinates
of the image.

reduce(factor=2, spline=False)[source]¶

Reduce the size of contour and data by the specified factor using slicing.

The method deletes the unused planes (keeps only every nth - n=factor). Can also use spline filters for up and downsampling.

factor : int if spline = False, float else
Specify the factor of reduction.
spline : boolean

*if False (default): use numpy slicing to reduce number of planes. *if True: use spline interpolation for reducing / enlarging data and

contour.
no return :
overwrite self.contour and self.data.
reset_results(keep=['points_in_feature'])[source]¶

Reset the result attribute.

Results to be kept can be specified. Keeps points_in_feature by default. If all results should be deleted use keep = []

keep : list of strings
List specifying the results to be kept. E.g. [‘points_in_feature’, ‘sphere_radius’] Note: Has to be list even if it only has one entry. Use [] for no results to be kept.
no return :
Overwrites self.results.
save(where)[source]¶

Saves the all data stored in an AutoPhenotype Object.

Recognises whether or not data is available and saves only available. Note: it is advised to create a new folder for every save, since multiple files are created which always have the same name. The following files are saved (if avaliable):

*data.tif : processed input data (e.g. reduced) as .tif stack *contour.tif : contour of data as .tif stack *mesh.vtp : mesh as vtk .vtp data (readable with

vtk.vtkXMLPolyDataReader() )
*featuresX.vtp : features in same format as mesh.vtp. Each feature
is a separate file and X is a running number starting from 0.
*results.csv : the results from e.g. the spherical fit as .csv
data generated with pandas DataFrame.to_csv().
where : string, path
Path to the folder in which the data should be saved. If folder does not exist, it is created.

set_contour_to_box()[source]¶

Set the contour attribute to a box.

The box consists of ones on the surfaces except the edges and the first plane on the first axis (axis = 0). The rest is zeros.

no return :
Overwrites contour.

smooth_contour(iterate=1)[source]¶

Smooth contour with ISoSI, SIoIS operators.

Uses the SIoIS and ISoSI operator of Marquez-Neila et al. 2014 (Section 3.5) to smooth the contour. At least one iteration after step is needed to get a good contour.

smooth_mesh(iterations=500, relaxation_factor=0.5, featureEdgeSmoothing=False, boundarySmoothing=True, feature_angle=30, edge_angle=15)[source]¶

Smooth mesh.

Uses vtk methods to clean and smooth the mesh. See documentation of vtkSmoothPolyData and vtkCleanPolyData for more info.

iterations : int
Number of iterations of the smooth algorithm.
relaxation_factor: float
Relaxation factor of the smooth algorithm.
no return :
Overwrites mesh.
sort_results(column='index', ascending=False, reset_index=False)[source]¶

Sort results by specified column.

The sorting direction can be adjusted.

column : str
Name of the column by which the array should be sorted. If column = ‘index’, the array will be sorted by its index
ascending : bool
Specifies the sorting direction:
*False: high->low *True: low->high
reset_index : bool
Reset the row index after sorting the array. If True, the order of self.features is also changed accordingly.
no return :
Overwrites results
sphere_evaluation()[source]¶

Add several results to self.results.

Added results are:
*’sphere_x_rel’: x-location of the primordium relative to the
meristem.
*’sphere_y_rel’: y-location of the primordium relative to the
meristem.
*’sphere_z_rel’: z-location of the primordium relative to the
meristem.

*’sphere_volume’: Volume of the sphere *’sphere_R’: Distance of the primordium to the meristem. *’sphere_angle_raw’: Angle between the primordia in the y,z plane.

Zero is chosen to be z = 0 and y > 0.

*–results missing–

Note: List of results is newly sorted in a way that the row with index 0 is the meristem. The row label is changed accordingly. Return —— no return :

Results are updated (see description).
sphere_fit()[source]¶

Fit spheres onto the features.

Iterates over the vtkPolyData objects in features and performs a least square fit of a sphere to each feature.

self.results : pandas.DataFrame
Four additional rows in self.results:
*sphere_x_abs: absolute x-coordinate of the center of the
fitted sphere
*sphere_y_abs: absolute y-coordinate of the center of the
fitted sphere
*sphere_z_abs: absolute z-coordinate of the center of the
fitted sphere

Note: absolute means in units of the coordinate system used in self.features.

step(weighting)[source]¶

Perform a single step of the morphological Chan-Vese evolution.

Implementation of the first two parts of Equation 32 in Marquez-Neila et al. 2014. (DOI: 10.1109/TPAMI.2013.106). The third part (smoothing) is implemented in the smooth_contour method.

weighting : float
Ratio of the weightings of the inside to outside intensity. (lambda_1/lambda_2 in Equation 32, where lambda_2 is chosen to be 1
no return :
Overwrite self.contour.

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.angle_difference(array)[source]¶

Return the differences between consecutive angles in an array.

Computes both clockwise and counterclockwise angle differences. Angles need to be in degree.

array : list with n entries
List of angles.
angle differences : list with two entries each with n-1 entries
*return[0]: clockwise angle differences *return[1]: counterclockwise angle differences
phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.array_from_vtk_polydata(poly, size=[])[source]¶

Create a boolean numpy array from vtkPolyData.

The size of the created numpy array can be specified. It has to be equal or larger than the bounds of the polydata. Scalar values in the polyData are ignored. All nonzero values in poly are transformed into ones in the return. Note: works only in 3D.

poly : vtkPolyData (3D)
polyData to be transformed.
size : tuple / list of int
Size of the created numpy array. By default set to the boundd of the polyData. e.g. (3,4,5)
array : numpy array
Boolean numpy array corresponding to the nonzero points in poly.

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.fit_paraboloid(data, init=[1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0])[source]¶

Fit a paraboloid to arbitrarily oriented 3D data.

The paraboloid data can by oriented along an arbitrary axis. Not neccesary x,y,z. The function rotates the data points and returns the rotation angles along the x,y,z axis. Returns the parameters for a praboloid along the z-axis. The angles can be used to correct the paraboloid for rotation. Paraboloid equation : p1*x**2.+p2*y**2.+p3*x+p4*y+p5 = z

data : array or list of cartesian coordinates
Cartesian coordinates of the data points.
init : list of 8 scalars
Initial parameter set. [p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, alpha, beta, gamma] *alpha: rotation around x axis *beta: rotation around y axis *gamma: rotation around z axis
popt : list of 8 scalars
Optimised parameters. [p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, alpha, beta, gamma] *alpha: rotation around x axis *beta: rotation around y axis *gamma: rotation around z axis
phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.fit_paraboloid_weighted(data, init=[1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0])[source]¶
phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.fit_sphere(data, init=[0, 0, 0, 10])[source]¶

Fit a sphere to specified data.

Uses a least square fit for optimisation. Return coordinates of the sphere center and its radius as well as the residual variance of the fit.

data : 3D numpy array
Data to be fit with a sphere
init : list
List of initial parameters: [x0, y0, z0, r0]
parameter : list
list of fitted parameters and residual variance: [x,y,z,r,res_var]

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.get_paraboloid_apex(p)[source]¶

Return the apex of a paraboloid.

Use the return of fit_paraboloid() to compute the apex of the paraboloid. The return is in the coordinate system of the data, meaning that the coordinates have been corected for the rotation angles.

p : list of 8 scalars
Optimised parameters. [p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, alpha, beta, gamma] *alpha: rotation around x axis *beta: rotation around y axis *gamma: rotation around z axis
coord : list
List of the apex’ [x,y,z] coordinates.

Create a 3D numpy array with zeros on the edges and ones else.

Used to suppress the fitting of edges by the smooth() function (ISoSI operator mask).

shape : tuple with three components
Shape of the returned array
array : numpy array with shape() = shape
Three dimensional numpy array with zeros on the edges and ones else.

Used as initial contour for the AutoPhenotype.step() method.

Shape of the returned array
invert : bool
*True: Ones on surface, zeros else *False: Zeros on surface, ones else

Create a logfile for saving and loading AutoPhenotype data from keywords

Uses keywords to generate a logfile. Keywords can be:
*’all’: everything below *’data’: input data as .tif *’contour’: contour fit as .tif *’mesh’: mesh as vtk data .vtp *’features’: features as vtk data .vtp *’results’: results as .csv
what : list of strings
Use specified strings from description. Note: has to be list, even if only one keyword is specified.
path = string

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.rgb_list(N, firstcolor=(), lastcolor=(), s=1.0, v=1.0)[source]¶

Generate a list of N distinct RGB tuples.

The first and last entry of the list can be specified. The list will still have N entries. The range of each tuple entry is between 0. and 1. The list goes from red over green to blue and purple.

N : int
Number of returned RGB-tuples.
firstcolor : list, three components
First entry of the returned RGB-list.
lastcolor : list, three components
Last entry of the returned RGB-list.
s : float between 0 and 1
Saturation value of the list
v : float between 0 and 1
Value value of the list
RGB-list : list of tuples with three components
List with N RGB-tuples

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.sort_a_along_b(b, a)[source]¶

Return list ‘a’ sorted following the sorting of list ‘b’.

List ‘b’ is sorted from low to high values. Elements in ‘a’ follow the sorting in list ‘b’. Example: to array

a = [p,c,e,s,e,i,l]; b = [5,2,7,6,1,4,3] -> sort_a_along_b(a,b) = [e,c,l,i,p,s,e]; # and b would be [1,2,3,4,5,6,7]
a : list (same length as b)
List to be sorted.
b : list (same length as a)
Reference list for sorting.
a’ : list
List ‘a’ sorted with respect to ‘b’.

phenotastic.domain_processing.define_meristem(mesh, pdata, method='central_mass', res=(0, 0, 0), fluo=None)[source]¶

Define which domain is the meristem.

mesh :

pdata :

method :
(Default value = ‘central_mass’)
res :
(Default value = (0)
fluo : np.ndarray
Fluorescence data matrix. Needed for method == central_space. TODO: Avoid needing this.
meristem, coord : int, tuple
Meristem domain index and coordinate tuple specifying the center coordinates.

phenotastic.domain_processing.merge_boas_distance(pdata, boas, bdata, distance)[source]¶

Merge basins of attraction based on their euclidian distance from one another.

Uses a KDTree to find closest points.

pdata : pandas.DataFrame

boas : np.ndarray

bdata : pandas.DataFrame

distance : float
Maximal allowed euclidean distance. Smaller distances than this will be merged.
pdata : pandas.DataFrame
New pdata object.
phenotastic.domain_processing.merge_boas_engulfing(A, pdata, threshold=0.9)[source]¶

Merge boas based on whether adjacent domains are encircling more than a certain fraction of the domain boundary.

TODO: Unfinished function. Needs a rewrite.

A : Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.AutoPhenotype

pdata : pandas.DataFrame

threshold : float
Minimum fraction enclosure needed in order to merge. (Default value = .9)

phenotastic.misc.spherefit_results(spheres)[source]¶

Legacy method retrieving results from a sphere-fit operation.

Gives several results from an array of spheres, such as distance between the first sphere (mersitem) and the other spheres (organs). Input:

np.array[[x_center_meristem, y_center_meristem, z_center_meristem, radius_mersitem],
[x_center_organ1, y_center_organ1, z_center_organ1, radius_organ1] …]
Output:
np.array[[voulme_meristem, 0,0,0,0,0,0]
[volume_organ1, location_organ1_realtive_to_meristem_x, y, z, r, theta, phi, projected_theta] …]

For spherical coordinates: xyz -> yzx Angles in radians, distances in voxel

spheres : list of sphere PolyData

phenotastic.misc.squared_dist_para(data, p, shiftx=0, shifty=0, shiftz=0, shiftcurv=0)[source]¶
